data.title: Proposal for distributable themes
data.body:
Following in the tradition of README driven development, I've outlined roughly how I think themes could work with APM.

Just to be clear, there is no code to support this currently but I felt that it was best to get my thoughts out after developing: https://github.com/atom/solarized-dark-syntax

Basically I think there are two things that make an APM package a theme:
- It has a `theme` attribute which is `true` in the `package.json` file.
- It can have a `stylesheets` attribute which indicates the loading order of the stylesheets.

Feedback is welcome (especially @benogle for the ui-variables stuff)

data.title: How do we do public Atom documentation?
data.body:
This is the first of a few issues I'm going to open about how we handle the non-software parts of the Atom product launch. The first question I'd like to pose is how we plan to handle the public documentation for Atom.
## Presentation

Will we be treating it like GitHub, with something like `help.atom.io` where docs live? Or will it go more of the open source project route, where you find docs in the repo directory?

I personally prefer the dedicated site route. It gives a better opportunity to provide nice docs for people that want to learn how Atom works, or how to mod it. This also lets us separate the concerns of learning how to use the app (website) from documentation about the development of the app (/docs folder).
## Content

Who will write the docs? We'll want to have docs at ship time, so thinking about this now will let us figure out who will be doing the work and perhaps get them started so they don't have to catch up at the last minute.

---

What are your thoughts?

data.title: ATomDoc: A scalable docs format proposal
data.body:
We've had some deep discussion on #747 :airplane: about the conventions we want to adopt for documenting our source code. On the one hand, we want to provide rich, browsable documentation for the consumers of our APIs. This is clearly critical to the success of our community. On the other hand, we we want the experience of _working_ with documented source code to be as smooth and lightweight as possible and keep our source files looking sexy.

So far, the discussion has been about the full fidelity of TomDoc vs. the compactness and lower maintenance burden of less a less formal approach. After pondering this for a while, I think that by innovating on our documentation format we can satisfy all of these concerns. With this PR, I'd like to start a conversation about what that format might look like.

While it's true that TomDoc is a standard of sorts, I don't think it's meeting our needs well. My main criticism is that it feels very bulky, and it's causing our source files to feel extremely cluttered. We need a format that's simple for simple methods–on the order of a single line–but that also scales smoothly to five, ten, or even more lines as the need for documentation increases. I think this proposal can provide that.

data.title: Seeking better tools for tracking memory churn
data.body:
I need a tool that can help me understand what regions of code are contributing most to GC pauses. What kind of objects are we churning, and where are they allocated? Everything I find about the Chromium heap profiler seems to be about fixing memory leaks, but I want to reduce GC pressure and that tool doesn't really seem suited for that purpose, unless I'm using it wrong. Heap snapshots only tell me about objects that haven't been collected, whereas I'm looking to find what objects we're collecting a lot of. Are there any deeper tools that could be adapted to this purpose, like perhaps by instrumenting V8? I know Aman has some experience in this kind of thing with memprof.rb.

Could a native badass give me some guidance? @tmm1 @aroben @vmg

data.title: Only run specs found in the current project's spec folder
data.body: Running specs while writing a package is painful. This lets you only run the specs from the package you are working on.

data.title: Moves all functionality from the weirdo `aa` script into the Atom cli script.
data.body:
Previously, browser process always loaded files from the application path `/Application/Atom.app`. `aa` would get around this problem by compiling certain coffee files needed by the browser process into the application path.

Now, when atom is run in dev mode all files (excluding main.coffee) are loaded from the resource path. I also added the command line flag -f or --foreground to keep the browser processes in the foreground. This allows us to see the output from the browser process.

data.title: Themes can change color of selected text
data.body:

This is useful so that you can increase the contrast of the selected text.

data.title: Cmd+G should always find the next instance
data.body:
When using Find to search a single file, you should be able to hit Cmd+G to find the "next" instance without ever having to hit Enter to execute the search. To be clear, Enter should still find the first instance, but Cmd+G should _always_ find the next one.

For comparison, see Sublime Text or Google Chrome.
